content: May 6, 1943, my parents were married. Mom was 18 dad was 23. Dad was stationed in Lincoln Nebraska when they married. Dad was Air Force. Mom worked at a plant in Lincoln making bullets/ammunition durng WWII. I don't have a pictures, but wished I did. Is there anyone here who has/had a mom during that time who was a part of our history of women as Rosie The Riveter. We must never forget the part that our women played during that time. I am very proud to know that my mom was part of our history. I do have this though....
reply: May 6, 1943, my parents were married. Mom was 18 dad was 23. Dad was stationed in Lincoln Nebraska when they married. Dad was Air Force. Mom worked at a plant in Lincoln making bullets/ammunition durng WWII. I don't have a pictures, but wished I did. Is there anyone here who has/had a mom during that time who was a part of our history of women as Rosie The Riveter. We must never forget the part that our women played during that time. I am very proud to know that my mom was part of our history. I do have this though....
title: Rosie The Riveter

content: Dad was stationed at McCook Field Neb where he trained in B-17s, B-24s and B-29s. Mom went with him to there, then when he shipped into the Pacific, she came back here to Utah and worked in the canneries that made meals for K-rations... This picture was taken of them at McCook. Hard to make out the pin she's wearing, but it's similar: Wandering and Wondering
reply: Dad was stationed at McCook Field Neb where he trained in B-17s, B-24s and B-29s. Mom went with him to there, then when he shipped into the Pacific, she came back here to Utah and worked in the canneries that made meals for K-rations... This picture was taken of them at McCook. Hard to make out the pin she's wearing, but it's similar: Wandering and Wondering

content: One day I was doing a lot of googling and found a website about Rosie. I then found on the site a lady's name and email address. This was her reply to my email. Hi Cindy, I made some calls last week about the Easy Manufacturing Company in Lincoln, Nebraska. Here are some people you could contact for more information. Nebraska Historical Society, collections department, Deb Arons, 402-471-4759 Lincoln Journal Star (they took the picture you sent me), 800-742-7315 Don Ammon, 402-488-0300, I think he is related to Charles Ammon who apparently owned the business in the 1930's and maybe the 1940's. Good luck. Carol
reply: One day I was doing a lot of googling and found a website about Rosie. I then found on the site a lady's name and email address. This was her reply to my email. Hi Cindy, I made some calls last week about the Easy Manufacturing Company in Lincoln, Nebraska. Here are some people you could contact for more information. Nebraska Historical Society, collections department, Deb Arons, 402-471-4759 Lincoln Journal Star (they took the picture you sent me), 800-742-7315 Don Ammon, 402-488-0300, I think he is related to Charles Ammon who apparently owned the business in the 1930's and maybe the 1940's. Good luck. Carol
title: Rosie The Riveter

content: Mom was a shipyard welder and later worked assembling the TBM Avenger. She drilled parts for riviting. But DO NOT call her Rosie the Riviter. She will tell you she drilled parts and welded but did not rivit. I tried to tell her it's just a nickname for women who worked in the defence plants but she will have none of it. today she lives in eastern Arizona with my step dad.
reply: Mom was a shipyard welder and later worked assembling the TBM Avenger. She drilled parts for riviting. But DO NOT call her Rosie the Riviter. She will tell you she drilled parts and welded but did not rivit. I tried to tell her it's just a nickname for women who worked in the defence plants but she will have none of it. today she lives in eastern Arizona with my step dad.
title: Rosie The Riveter

title: Rosie The Riveter

content: quote: Originally posted by RetiredMarineWife: Scooter, your mom is a hoot. I wished I could talk to my mom about this, she died 2/22/98. Mom always attributed her welding skills to her excellent penmanship. I believer her. She did SMAW, shielded metal arc welding, "stick" for short. I tried to learn it but was never very good. My handwriting is lousy too. I CAN TIG weld aluminum though... Sorry to hear about your mom's passing. I bet she was awesome.
quote: Originally posted by RetiredMarineWife: Scooter, your mom is a hoot. I wished I could talk to my mom about this, she died 2/22/98.

My handwriting is lousy too. I CAN TIG weld aluminum though... Sorry to hear about your mom's passing. I bet she was awesome.

title: Rosie The Riveter

content: When my Grandmom (Dad’s mom) was in the 6th grade her and her 3-siblings ended up in the Salvation Army’s Children’s Home. My Grandmom was the oldest of her 2-sisters and 1-brother. The Salvation Army helped her get a job in a sewing factory and an apartment so her brother and sisters could stay in school and stay together. She later went on to volunteer with the Salvation Army and stayed involved long after I was born. Salvation Army Children’s Home ~ Egg Harbor City, NJ Florence, Joe, Edna, & Francis - on the right Salvation Army Children’s Home ~ Egg Harbor City, NJ Woman facing camera is my Grandmom choose joy each day
reply: When my Grandmom (Dad’s mom) was in the 6th grade her and her 3-siblings ended up in the Salvation Army’s Children’s Home. My Grandmom was the oldest of her 2-sisters and 1-brother. The Salvation Army helped her get a job in a sewing factory and an apartment so her brother and sisters could stay in school and stay together. She later went on to volunteer with the Salvation Army and stayed involved long after I was born. content: quote: Originally posted by RetiredMarineWife: Scooter, your mom is a hoot. I wished I could talk to my mom about this, she died 2/22/98. Mom always attributed her welding skills to her excellent penmanship. I believer her. She did SMAW, shielded metal arc welding, "stick" for short. I tried to learn it but was never very good. My handwriting is lousy too. I CAN TIG weld aluminum though... Sorry to hear about your mom's passing. I bet she was awesome.
quote: Originally posted by RetiredMarineWife: Scooter, your mom is a hoot. I wished I could talk to my mom about this, she died 2/22/98.

title: Rosie The Riveter

content: When my Grandmom (Dad’s mom) was in the 6th grade her and her 3-siblings ended up in the Salvation Army’s Children’s Home. My Grandmom was the oldest of her 2-sisters and 1-brother. The Salvation Army helped her get a job in a sewing factory and an apartment so her brother and sisters could stay in school and stay together. She later went on to volunteer with the Salvation Army and stayed involved long after I was born. Salvation Army Children’s Home ~ Egg Harbor City, NJ Florence, Joe, Edna, & Francis - on the right Salvation Army Children’s Home ~ Egg Harbor City, NJ Woman facing camera is my Grandmom choose joy each day

content: My mom was a riviter at Boeing Aircraft company in Seattle during the war. Didn't pay much but she made a living at it while my dad was over in the Philipines.
